attributes.p: Modernism made an impact early in the 20th century century. Artists such as the Henri Matisse, the Norwegian Edvard Munch (whose 1893 Scream summed up modern urban alienation) and the Austrian Oskar Kokoschka used vivid colours and broad brushstrokes to express mood and emotion, and the personal feelings evoked by a situation rather than the way it literally looked. Much avant-garde modernist culture – books such as James Joyce's Ulysses, poems such as T. S. Eliot's The Waste Land and Ezra Pound's Hugh Selwyn Mauberley, modern art, modern architecture, ballets staged by Sergei Diaghilev – was, for most of the first half of the 20th century, only enjoyed by small groups of intellectuals. The public reacted with jeers and contempt to Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring, and D.H. Lawrence's Lady Chatterley's Lover has been banned in the UK for several decades. Whereas Pirandello's Six Characters in Search of an Author and Ionesco's Rhinoceros shaped the face of modernism in the theatre, their first stagings attracted extremely hostile public reactions.
